dt.t: The factory was to be a vast installation, {wi}comprising{/wi} fifty buildings.
… a misconception as to what {wi}comprises{/wi} a literary generation.
… about 8 percent of our military forces are {it}comprised{/it} of women.

dt: {bc}to include especially within a particular scope

dt.t: … civilization as Lenin used the term would then certainly have {wi}comprised{/wi} the changes that are now associated in our minds with "developed" rather than "developing" states.

pt: Although it has been in use since the late 18th century, sense 2 is still attacked as wrong. Why it has been singled out is not clear, but until comparatively recent times it was found chiefly in scientific or technical writing rather than belles lettres. Our current evidence shows a slight shift in usage: sense 2 is somewhat more frequent in recent literary use than the earlier senses. You should be aware, however, that if you use sense 2 you may be subject to criticism for doing so, and you may want to choose a safer synonym such as {it}compose{/it} or {it}make up.{/it}

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}compris{/it}, past participle of {it}comprendre{/it}, from Latin {it}comprehendere{/it} {dx_ety}see {dxt|comprehend||}{/dx_ety}
shortdef: to include especially within a particular scope

dt.t: The play is {it}comprised of{/it} three acts.
